articles.headline: French Bank Says Rogue Trader Lost $7 Billion
articles.snippet: Société Générale said the trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.
articles.abstract: Société Générale said the trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  A French bank announced Thursday that it had lost $7.2 billion, not because of complex subprime loans, but the old-fashioned way  because a 31-year-old rogue trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and David Jolly

articles.headline: At Ford, Chief Intends to Get Its Units in Sync
articles.snippet: With the shrinking of Ford’s core United States business nearly completed, chief executive Alan R. Mulally is eager to get Ford’s global operations hitting on all cylinders.
articles.abstract: With the shrinking of Ford’s core United States business nearly completed, chief executive Alan R. Mulally is eager to get Ford’s global operations hitting on all cylinders.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  At a town hall meeting with employees on Thursday at the Ford Motor Company headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive, pulled out a laminated card emblazoned with the words “One Ford” and the company’s blue oval logo.

articles.headline: Familiarity Breeds Gloom Among Financial Experts
articles.snippet: Pessimism is greatest among those closest to the financial system, so while some take a working financial system for granted, others see a system in crisis.
articles.abstract: Pessimism is greatest among those closest to the financial system, so while some take a working financial system for granted, others see a system in crisis.

articles.headline: Throughout Asia, Exporters Brace for Tremors From a U.S. Pullback
articles.snippet: Rather than waiting for the American economy to get worse, companies in Asia are changing how they operate.
articles.abstract: Rather than waiting for the American economy to get worse, companies in Asia are changing how they operate.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Asian exporters are already feeling the effects of an American economic downturn  effects that may be magnified by a weak dollar, volatile world markets and fears that more bad loans may be ticking in the coffers of American companies.

articles.headline: U.S. Asking Iraq for Wide Rights on War
articles.snippet: With its authority in Iraq set to expire, the Bush administration will also seek to guarantee civilian contractors specific legal protections from Iraqi law, according to administration and military officials.
articles.abstract: With its authority in Iraq set to expire, the Bush administration will also seek to guarantee civilian contractors specific legal protections from Iraqi law, according to administration and military officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With its international mandate in Iraq set to expire in 11 months, the Bush administration will insist that the government in Baghdad give the United States broad authority to conduct combat operations and guarantee civilian contractors specific legal protections from Iraqi law, according to administration and military officials.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: A Spiral of Losses by a ‘Plain Vanilla’ Trader
articles.snippet: On Thursday, the world came to know Jérôme Kerviel, 31, as the most dangerous accused rogue trader ever.
articles.abstract: On Thursday, the world came to know Jérôme Kerviel, 31, as the most dangerous accused rogue trader ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  On the elite trading floors here, where France’s brightest minds devise some of the most complex instruments in global finance, few people noticed Jérôme Kerviel.

articles.headline: Trading Partners Fear U.S. Consumers Won’t Continue Free-Spending Ways
articles.snippet: Some fear that American consumers will pull back from their exuberant spending, cooling demand for goods worldwide and dragging down the global economy.
articles.abstract: Some fear that American consumers will pull back from their exuberant spending, cooling demand for goods worldwide and dragging down the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, many experts were convinced that a vibrant world economy would prevent an American recession. Even if the beleaguered American consumer suddenly turned thrifty, they reasoned, healthy spending on other shores was supposed to keep the expansion rolling.

articles.headline: Microsoft Delivers Strong Growth and Includes a Sunny Forecast
articles.snippet: The company’s strong quarterly results and optimistic outlook suggest that a weakening economy will not slow it down.
articles.abstract: The company’s strong quarterly results and optimistic outlook suggest that a weakening economy will not slow it down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profit gains that surpassed Wall Street’s expectations and delivered an optimistic outlook Thursday, suggesting that a weakening economy would not slow it down.
